avg-node-1.title: Understanding Measures of Central Tendency
learningFocus: Understand that an average is a measure of central tendency
Recognize that averages represent the 'centre' of a dataset
Know that there are three types of averages: mean, median, and mode

exemplarProblems.problemText: What does it mean when we say an average is a 'measure of central tendency'?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: A measure of central tendency tells us where the data points are centred about. It represents the data set with a single value that indicates the typical or central value in the distribution.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Name the three types of averages used in statistics.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: The three types of averages are: (1) Mean (arithmetic average), (2) Median (middle value), and (3) Mode (most frequent value).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE conceptual question about averages
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for conceptual understanding
Focus on WHAT an average represents, not HOW to calculate
Students should understand: average = single value representing entire dataset
Emphasize that different situations require different types of averages
Connect to real-world: life expectancy, median age, average household size

avg-node-2.title: Why Different Types of Averages
learningFocus: Understand that different scenarios require different averages
Recognize that each average has advantages and limitations
Preview when to use mean, median, or mode

exemplarProblems.problemText: In a company, most employees earn around $2000-$2800 per month, but the CEO earns $10,000. Would the mean salary give a good picture of what most employees earn? Why or why not?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: No, the mean would not give a good picture. The CEO's high salary ($10,000) is an extreme value that would pull the mean much higher than what most employees actually earn. The mean would suggest employees earn more than they really do. The median would be more appropriate here.

extremeValueScenarios: Salaries with one very high earner
House prices with a few mansions
Test scores with one very low score
Ages with one very old person

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE scenario-based question
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Present scenario where one type of average is clearly better than another
Common scenario: extreme values affecting mean
Students should explain WHY one average is better, not just identify which
Connect to real decision-making: choosing fair representation

avg-node-3.title: Calculating Mean of Raw Data
learningFocus: Apply formula: Mean = sum of data values / number of data values
Distinguish between data values and number of data values
Calculate mean from small datasets

exemplarProblems.problemText: The numbers of books borrowed by 5 students from a library are 3, 4, 4, 9, and 10. Calculate the mean number of books borrowed.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Mean = sum of data values / number of data values = (3 + 4 + 4 + 9 + 10) / 5 = 30 / 5 = 6 books

exemplarProblems.problemText: The heights of 7 students are 1.54 m, 1.67 m, 1.49 m, 1.54 m, 1.76 m, 1.69 m, and 1.58 m. Calculate the mean height.

variationRules.keyReminder: Data values are the actual numbers; number of data values is the count (n)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE calculation from raw data (5-8 values)
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Formula: Mean = sum / n
Emphasize distinction: sum OF values vs number OF values
Use realistic contexts from curriculum: books, heights, ages, scores
Values should give non-integer means to show division properly
Students must show formula, substitution, and final answer

avg-node-4.title: Finding Unknown Given Mean
learningFocus: Use mean formula to find unknown data value
Rearrange: sum of data values = mean × number of data values
Set up and solve equations involving mean

exemplarProblems.problemText: The mean of $10, $15, $12, $20, and $x is $13. Find the value of x.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Mean = sum / n, so 13 = (10 + 15 + 12 + 20 + x) / 5. Therefore 13 × 5 = 57 + x, which gives 65 = 57 + x, so x = 8.

exemplarProblems.problemText: The mean of six numbers is 17. Four of the numbers are 15, 17, 20, and 22. The remaining two numbers are equal. Find the two remaining numbers.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Sum of all six numbers = mean × n = 17 × 6 = 102. Sum of known four = 15 + 17 + 20 + 22 = 74. Sum of two remaining = 102 - 74 = 28. Since they're equal, each = 28 / 2 = 14.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE problem finding unknown from given mean
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key insight: mean × number of values = sum of values
Problem types: (a) find single unknown x, (b) find two equal unknowns
Students must: set up equation, rearrange, solve
Show working clearly: Mean × n = sum, then solve for unknown
Use realistic contexts where possible

avg-node-5.title: Mean from Frequency Table
learningFocus: Understand frequency distribution vs raw data
Apply formula: Mean = Σfx / Σf
Calculate products of value × frequency

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Weekly salary ($) | 1000 | 1100 | 1200 | 2100 | 2500
Number of employees | 20 | 8 | 10 | 7 | 5

Calculate the mean weekly salary of the employees.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE frequency table problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Formula: Mean = Σfx / Σf where x=value, f=frequency
Students must: (1) find Σf (total frequency), (2) calculate each fx, (3) find Σfx, (4) divide
Emphasize: sum of data values = Σfx, NOT just Σx
Provide table with 4-6 rows
Use realistic contexts from curriculum

avg-node-6.title: Understanding 'Even Out' Concept
learningFocus: Visualize mean as 'leveling out' all values
Understand that if everyone had the mean value, total would be same
Connect to real-world: fair distribution

exemplarProblems.problemText: Five students have 3, 4, 4, 9, and 10 books. The mean is 6 books. What does it mean if we say 'the mean evens out the values'?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: If we redistribute the books so everyone has the same number (6 books each), the total would remain 30 books (5 × 6 = 30). The mean represents the value each person would have if we 'evened out' or distributed the books equally.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE conceptual question about 'even out' idea
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key concept: mean × n = total (if everyone had mean value)
Students should explain the leveling/distribution concept
Connect to: If Vani had 7 sweets and everyone got x (mean), each would have x
Real-world connection: fair distribution, equal sharing

avg-node-7.title: Why Not to Average Averages
learningFocus: Understand that averaging means from different-sized groups gives wrong answer
Recognize that bases (group sizes) matter
Calculate correct overall mean using weighted approach

exemplarProblems.problemText: Class A has 20 students with a mean score of 70. Class B has 30 students with a mean score of 80. What is the mean score for all 50 students? Is it simply (70 + 80) / 2 = 75?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: No, we cannot just average the two means because the classes have different sizes (different bases). Correct calculation: Total score for Class A = 20 × 70 = 1400. Total score for Class B = 30 × 80 = 2400. Overall mean = (1400 + 2400) / (20 + 30) = 3800 / 50 = 76 (not 75).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE problem about averaging means from different-sized groups
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key lesson: Cannot average means when bases (group sizes) differ
Correct method: (sum1 + sum2) / (n1 + n2) where sum = mean × n
Students must explain WHY simple average of means is wrong
Emphasize: the bases may be different

avg-node-8.title: Estimating Mean from Grouped Data
learningFocus: Understand that grouped data loses exact values
Use mid-value to represent class interval
Calculate: mid-value = (lower boundary + upper boundary) / 2
Recognize result is an estimate, not exact mean

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Time (minutes) | 15 ≤ x < 20 | 20 ≤ x < 25 | 25 ≤ x < 30 | 30 ≤ x < 35 | 35 ≤ x < 40
Frequency | 5 | 10 | 20 | 15 | 18

Estimate the mean time.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE grouped data problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key steps: (1) Find mid-value for each interval, (2) Calculate fx for each, (3) Sum to get Σfx, (4) Divide by Σf
Emphasize: This is an ESTIMATE because we don't know exact values, only intervals
Mid-value formula: (lower + upper) / 2 for interval a ≤ x < b
Provide 4-5 class intervals with frequencies
Students must show all mid-values and fx calculations

avg-node-9.title: Position of Median - Odd Number
learningFocus: Arrange data in ascending order first
Use formula: Position = (n+1)/2 for odd n
Identify median as the middle value

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find the median of: 20, 25, 21, 24, 22, 26, 20
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Step 1: Arrange in ascending order: 20, 20, 21, 22, 24, 25, 26. Step 2: n = 7 (odd). Position of median = (7+1)/2 = 4. Step 3: The 4th value is 22. Therefore, median = 22.

exemplarProblems.problemText: The ages of 9 participants are: 32, 15, 20, 15, 25, 12, 18, 22, 19. Find the median age.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Arrange in order: 12, 15, 15, 18, 19, 20, 22, 25, 32. n = 9 (odd). Position = (9+1)/2 = 5. The 5th value is 19. Median = 19 years.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE median problem with ODD number of values
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Students must: (1) Arrange in order, (2) Calculate position (n+1)/2, (3) Find value at that position
Use n = 5, 7, or 9 values
Present data UNSORTED to test ordering skill
Emphasize: MUST arrange in order first
Position formula gives single middle value for odd n

avg-node-10.title: Position of Median - Even Number
learningFocus: Use formula: Position = (n+1)/2 for even n (gives decimal)
Median lies BETWEEN two middle values
Calculate median as mean of two middle values

exemplarProblems.problemText: Find the median of: 12, 8, 19, 30, 14, 21, 9, 5
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Arrange in order: 5, 8, 9, 12, 14, 19, 21, 30. n = 8 (even). Position = (8+1)/2 = 4.5. This means median lies between 4th and 5th values. 4th value = 12, 5th value = 14. Median = (12 + 14)/2 = 13.

variationRules.medianCalculation: Median = mean of two middle values

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE median problem with EVEN number of values
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Students must: (1) Arrange in order, (2) Calculate position (n+1)/2, (3) Recognize decimal position means BETWEEN two values, (4) Average the two middle values
Use n = 6, 8, or 10 values
Key insight: Position 4.5 means median is between 4th and 5th values
Emphasize: Median = (4th value + 5th value) / 2
Present data unsorted

avg-node-11.title: Finding Unknown Given Median
learningFocus: Use median definition to set up equation
Consider position of median
Solve for unknown value

exemplarProblems.problemText: The median of 9, 3, 6, 7, 5 and x is 6.5. Find a possible value of x.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: n = 6 (even), so position = 3.5, meaning median is mean of 3rd and 4th values. If median = 6.5, then (3rd + 4th)/2 = 6.5, so 3rd + 4th = 13. Arranging known values: 3, 5, 6, 7, 9. For median to be 6.5, we need 3rd + 4th = 13. If x is between 6 and 7 (say x = 6.5), order becomes: 3, 5, 6, 6.5, 7, 9. Then 3rd = 6, 4th = 6.5, and (6+6.5)/2 = 6.25 ≠ 6.5. Try x = 7: order is 3, 5, 6, 7, 7, 9. Then (6+7)/2 = 6.5 ✓. So x = 7 works.

problemTypes: Given median position, deduce x location

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE problem finding unknown from given median
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key approach: Determine what the middle value(s) must be, then find where x fits
For even n: median = (value at n/2 + value at n/2+1) / 2
Students must consider ordering and position
May have multiple possible answers - ask for 'a possible value'

avg-node-12.title: Median from Dot Diagram
learningFocus: Count total number of data values (sum of frequencies)
Find position of median
Count from left to locate median value

exemplarProblems.problemText: The dot diagram shows visits to a supermarket in a week. Find the median number of visits.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Count total dots: 1+1+3+4+3+1 = 13 data values. Position = (13+1)/2 = 7. Count from left: 1st at 1, 2nd at 2, 3rd-5th at 3 (three dots), 6th-9th at 4 (four dots). The 7th value is at 4. Median = 4 visits.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE median problem from dot diagram
CRITICAL: Include dotDiagram mathTool
Students must: (1) Count total n, (2) Find position, (3) Count through dots to locate median
Use 10-15 total data values
Counting method: 1st dot = 1, 2nd dot = 2, etc., until reaching position
Emphasize: Each dot = one data value

avg-node-13.title: Median from Stem-and-Leaf
learningFocus: Count total leaves (data values)
Find median position
Count through leaves to locate median
Leaves must be sorted within each stem

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Stem-and-leaf diagram:
3 | 5 6 6 7 8
4 | 0 1 2 3 4 7 8 9
5 | 0 1

Key: 3|5 means 3.5 km

Find the median distance.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Count total leaves: 5 + 8 + 2 = 15 values. Position = (15+1)/2 = 8. Count from top: leaves 1-5 in stem 3, leaves 6-13 in stem 4. The 8th value is the 3rd leaf in stem 4, which is 4|2 = 4.2 km. Median = 4.2 km.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE median problem from stem-and-leaf
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for stem-and-leaf
Students must: (1) Count all leaves, (2) Find position, (3) Count through leaves systematically
Provide 3-4 stems with 10-20 total leaves
Leaves MUST be sorted in ascending order (left to right)
Include clear key explaining notation
Counting tip: Count leaves within each stem, keep running total

avg-node-14.title: Understanding Median vs Mean with Outliers
learningFocus: Median is not affected by extreme values
Mean IS affected by extreme values
Compare both measures for same dataset

exemplarProblems.problemText: Company A salaries: $2000, $2100, $2700, $2400, $2200, $2000, $10,000, $2800, $2600. (a) Calculate mean and median. (b) Which gives a better picture of typical salary? Why?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Mean = ($2000+$2100+$2700+$2400+$2200+$2000+$10000+$2800+$2600)/9 = $28800/9 = $3200. For median: arrange: $2000, $2000, $2100, $2200, $2400, $2600, $2700, $2800, $10000. Position = 5. Median = $2400. (b) Median gives better picture. The $10,000 salary (CEO) is an extreme value that pulls the mean up to $3200, but most employees earn around $2000-$2800. The median of $2400 better represents typical salary.

scenarios: Salaries with one very high earner
Test scores with one very low score
House prices with few expensive houses
Ages with one very old person

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE comparison problem with extreme value
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Dataset should have 7-10 values with ONE clear outlier
Students must: (a) calculate both mean and median, (b) explain which is more appropriate
Key insight: Extreme value affects mean significantly but median hardly at all
This introduces why median is sometimes preferred

avg-node-15.title: Finding Mode from Raw Data
learningFocus: Mode = value that appears most frequently
Identify highest frequency by counting
Recognize that mode can be any type of data (numerical or categorical)

exemplarProblems.problemText: The numbers of books 10 students read in a year are: 8, 9, 10, 10, 3, 5, 6, 10, 6, 1. Find the mode.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Count frequencies: 1 appears 1 time, 3 appears 1 time, 5 appears 1 time, 6 appears 2 times, 8 appears 1 time, 9 appears 1 time, 10 appears 3 times. The value 10 appears most frequently (3 times). Mode = 10 books.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Blouse sizes sold: 8, 8, 10, 8, 10, 12, 10, 8, 8, 12. Find the mode. Explain why the mode is useful for the shop owner.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Size 8 appears 5 times, size 10 appears 3 times, size 12 appears 2 times. Mode = size 8. This tells the shop owner that size 8 is the most popular size, so they should stock more of this size.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE mode problem from raw data
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Students must identify value with highest frequency
Dataset: 10-12 values with one value appearing 3-4 times
Mode definition: value(s) with highest frequency, NOT the frequency itself
Connect to practical use: what's most common/popular

avg-node-16.title: Mode from Frequency Table
learningFocus: Mode = data value with highest frequency
Mode is NOT the highest frequency number itself
Look for largest value in frequency column, then identify corresponding data value

exemplarProblems.problemText:
Commission ($) | 1000 | 1200 | 1500 | 2000
Number of salesmen | 2 | 5 | 3 | 1

State the mode of the frequency distribution.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: The highest frequency is 5 (salesmen). This corresponds to commission of $1200. Mode = $1200 (NOT 5). The mode is the DATA VALUE with highest frequency.

variationRules.commonError: Mode is the data value, NOT the frequency

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE mode problem from frequency table
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide table with 4-5 data values and corresponding frequencies
One frequency should be clearly highest
CRITICAL REMINDER: Mode = data value with highest frequency, NOT the frequency itself
Common error: stating frequency instead of data value

avg-node-17.title: Bimodal and No Mode
learningFocus: Dataset can have more than one mode (bimodal, multimodal)
Dataset can have no mode (all values same frequency)
Understand these special cases

exemplarProblems.problemText: Dataset: 5, 7, 7, 9, 9, 12. (a) Find the mode(s). (b) What do we call this type of distribution?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Both 7 and 9 appear twice (highest frequency). Modes = 7 and 9. (b) This is called bimodal because there are two modes.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Dataset: 3, 5, 8, 11, 14. Find the mode.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Each value appears exactly once (frequency = 1 for all). Since all have the same frequency, there is no mode. We say this dataset has no mode.

specialCases.description: Two values with same highest frequency
Three or more values with same highest frequency

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE problem about bimodal OR no mode
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Bimodal: Two values appear same number of times (more than others)
No mode: All values appear same number of times
Students should state both/all modes for bimodal
Emphasize: 'bimodal' terminology
These are valid situations, not errors

avg-node-18.title: Understanding Mode Changes
learningFocus: Mode can change when data values are added or removed
Analyze how adding/removing values affects mode
Multiple values might need to be added to change mode

exemplarProblems.problemText: Ribbon lengths: 100 cm, 110 cm, 95 cm, 60 cm, 20 cm, 60 cm, 110 cm, 88 cm, 102 cm, 120 cm. (i) State the modal length. (ii) If a ribbon of length 110 cm is removed, what will the new modal length be?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (i) Count frequencies: 110 cm appears 2 times, 60 cm appears 2 times, all others appear once. Modes = 60 cm and 110 cm (bimodal). (ii) If one 110 cm ribbon removed, 110 appears 1 time and 60 appears 2 times. New mode = 60 cm (only one mode now).

changeTypes: Add value to create new mode
Add value to change bimodal to single mode

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE problem about mode changing
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Present initial dataset and ask for mode
Then modify dataset (add or remove value) and ask for new mode
Students must recalculate frequencies after modification
Tests understanding that mode depends on current frequencies

avg-node-19.title: When to Use Mean
learningFocus: Mean is preferred when there are NO extreme values
Mean takes into account ALL data values
Mean is most commonly used average

exemplarProblems.problemText: Test scores: 72, 75, 68, 71, 69, 73, 70, 74, 68, 72. Should you use mean, median, or mode to represent typical performance? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Mean is most appropriate. The scores are all close together (68-75) with no extreme values. The mean takes into account all the scores and will give an accurate picture of typical performance. All three measures would be similar, but mean is preferred when there are no outliers.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE scenario where mean is appropriate
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Dataset should have no extreme values (all values relatively close)
Students should identify mean as best choice AND explain why
Key reasoning: No outliers, so mean accurately represents centre
Mean advantage: Uses ALL data in calculation

avg-node-20.title: When to Use Median
learningFocus: Median is preferred when there ARE extreme values
Median is not affected by outliers
Median gives better picture when mean is distorted

exemplarProblems.problemText: House prices in a neighborhood: $300,000, $320,000, $350,000, $310,000, $330,000, $2,500,000. Should you use mean or median to represent typical house price? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Median is more appropriate. The $2,500,000 house is an extreme value (outlier) that would pull the mean much higher than what most houses cost. Mean would be misleading. The median would better represent the typical house price in this neighborhood because it's not affected by the one expensive house.

medianAppropriate: Salaries with CEO earning much more
Test scores with one student scoring very low
Ages with one very old person

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE scenario where median is appropriate
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Dataset must have clear outlier(s)
Students should: (1) identify median as best, (2) explain outlier affects mean, (3) explain median is resistant to outliers
Key advantage: Median gives true centre when extremes distort mean

avg-node-21.title: When to Use Mode
learningFocus: Mode is appropriate when finding most common/popular value
Mode works for categorical data (mean and median don't)
Mode is useful for discrete data with repeated values

exemplarProblems.problemText: A clothing store records sizes sold: 8, 10, 8, 12, 8, 10, 14, 8, 10, 8, 12. Which average should the store use to decide which size to stock most? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Mode is most appropriate. Mode = size 8 (appears 5 times). The store wants to know which size is most popular/common so they can stock more of it. Mean and median don't make sense for sizes (what does 'average size 9.5' mean?). The mode tells them directly: stock more size 8.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Favorite colors: Red, Blue, Blue, Green, Red, Blue, Yellow, Blue. Which average can you use?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Only mode can be used for categorical data like colors. Mode = Blue (appears 4 times). Mean and median don't make sense for categorical data because colors can't be added or ordered numerically.

modeAppropriate: Most common number of children per family

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE scenario where mode is appropriate
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Two main cases: (1) categorical data (colors, foods), (2) discrete numerical (sizes) where 'most common' matters
Students should explain: mode shows what's most popular/common
Key insight: For categorical data, mean and median impossible; only mode works
For sizes: Mode tells which to stock most

avg-node-22.title: Comparing All Three Measures
learningFocus: Calculate all three measures for same dataset
Compare their values
Understand how they differ and what each tells us

exemplarProblems.problemText: Dataset: 5, 6, 7, 7, 8, 8, 8, 9, 20. Calculate (a) mean, (b) median, (c) mode. (d) Which measure is most affected by the value 20? Why?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Mean = (5+6+7+7+8+8+8+9+20)/9 = 78/9 = 8.67. (b) Median: n=9, position=5. Arranged: 5,6,7,7,8,8,8,9,20. Median = 8. (c) Mode = 8 (appears 3 times). (d) Mean is most affected by 20. Without 20, mean ≈ 7.25, but with 20, mean = 8.67. Median stays same (8) and mode stays same (8) whether 20 is included or not.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE problem calculating all three measures
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Dataset: 8-10 values with one clear outlier
Students must calculate all three and compare
Key comparison: Which is affected by outlier? (Mean)
This solidifies understanding of when each is appropriate

avg-node-23.title: Finding Dataset Given Averages
learningFocus: Work backwards from given measures
Use constraints to deduce possible values
Apply understanding of mean, median, and mode definitions

exemplarProblems.problemText: Five numbers have a mean of 9, a median of 11, and a mode of 12. The largest number is four times the smallest number. Find the five numbers.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Since median = 11 and n = 5 (odd), the 3rd number is 11. Since mode = 12, at least two numbers are 12. They must be 4th and 5th (larger than median 11). So: _, _, 11, 12, 12. Mean = 9 means sum = 9 × 5 = 45. So first two numbers sum to 45 - 11 - 12 - 12 = 10. If smallest = a, largest = 12, but 'largest is four times smallest' means 12 = 4a, so a = 3. Then 3 + ? = 10, so ? = 7. Check: 3, 7, 11, 12, 12. Sum = 45, mean = 9 ✓. Median = 11 ✓. Mode = 12 ✓. Largest/smallest = 12/3 = 4 ✓. Answer: 3, 7, 11, 12, 12.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE reverse-engineering problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide mean, median, mode and additional constraint
Students must use definitions backwards to construct dataset
Requires deep understanding of all three measures
Check: verify that constructed dataset satisfies all conditions

avg-node-24.title: Real-World Applications and Decision Making
learningFocus: Apply knowledge to real decision-making scenarios
Justify which average to use in practical contexts
Understand implications of choosing wrong average

exemplarProblems.problemText: A company advertises 'average salary $4500'. The salaries are: $2000, $2200, $2100, $2300, $2000, $2400, $15000 (owner). (a) Is the company using mean or median? (b) Which average would be more honest for job seekers to know? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Calculate: Mean = ($2000+$2200+$2100+$2300+$2000+$2400+$15000)/7 = $28000/7 = $4000 (not $4500). Median: arranged: $2000, $2000, $2100, $2200, $2300, $2400, $15000. Position 4 → median = $2200. They might be using neither exactly, but closer to mean. (b) Median would be more honest. Most employees earn around $2000-$2400. The owner's $15000 is an outlier that inflates the mean. Job seekers should know the median ($2200) to understand what typical employees actually earn.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE real-world decision scenario
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Present scenario where choice of average matters
Students should: (1) calculate relevant averages, (2) identify which is being used/should be used, (3) explain implications
Connect to ethics: Can averages be used misleadingly?
Emphasize informed decision-making

avg-node-25.title: Effect of Systematic Measurement Error
learningFocus: Understand how systematic errors affect averages
If all values have same error, correct the average
Apply error correction to mean, median, and mode

exemplarProblems.problemText: Siti weighed seven oranges. The modal mass was 148 g, the median mass was 153 g, and the mean mass was 153.7 g. The weighing machine was inaccurate: each orange was actually 18 g MORE than recorded. Write the correct modal, median, and mean masses.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Since EVERY orange was 18 g heavier than measured, we add 18 g to each average: Correct mode = 148 + 18 = 166 g. Correct median = 153 + 18 = 171 g. Correct mean = 153.7 + 18 = 171.7 g.

errorTypes: Systematic error (all values too high/low by same amount)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE systematic error problem
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide averages calculated from incorrect measurements
State systematic error amount
Students correct each average by adding/subtracting error
Key insight: If ALL values off by constant, add/subtract constant from average
This applies to mean, median, AND mode
